steps.title: Take off any handles or knobs from the furniture.
steps.content: Take off any handles or knobs from the furniture. Put them in a plastic bag so you don’t lose them. If something won’t detach from the furniture, cover it with painter’s tape.

steps.title: Fill in dents in the furniture with a wood filler.
steps.content: Fill in dents in the furniture with a wood filler. You can find wood filler at your local hardware store. Let the filler dry per the instructions on the label. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Use a 120-grit sandpaper to lightly sand the furniture’s surface.
steps.content: Use a 120-grit sandpaper to lightly sand the furniture’s surface. [2] X Expert Source James Guth Painting Specialist Expert Interview. 21 July 2020. Sand in circular motions until the surface of the furniture looks dull and less glossy. Don’t sand too much or you might tear up the laminate from the surface. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Wipe down the furniture with a damp cloth to remove any wood dust.
steps.content: Wipe down the furniture with a damp cloth to remove any wood dust. Make sure the surface of the furniture is clean before you begin the priming process. [4] X Expert Source James Guth Painting Specialist Expert Interview. 21 July 2020.

steps.title: Lay down a tarp in a well-ventilated area.
steps.content: Lay down a tarp in a well-ventilated area. Move the furniture onto the tarp so no primer or paint gets on the floor. Use newspaper if you don't have a tarp.

steps.title: Apply a high-quality latex primer to the furniture’s surface.
steps.content: Apply a high-quality latex primer to the furniture’s surface. [5] X Expert Source James Guth Painting Specialist Expert Interview. 21 July 2020. Look for primer at your local hardware or paint store. Apply the primer using a brush or roller until there’s an even coverage on the entire surface of the furniture. [6] X Research source Use a spray can primer for an easier application.

steps.title: Let the primer dry for at least four hours.
steps.content: Let the primer dry for at least four hours. After four hours, gently touch the primed surface with the tip of your finger to see if it’s fully dried. If the primer is still wet, let it finish drying. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Sand the primed surface with a 220-grit sandpaper.
steps.content: Sand the primed surface with a 220-grit sandpaper. Lightly sand in circular motions like you did the first time you sanded the furniture. Wipe off any dust from the surface with a damp cloth. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Use an acrylic latex paint.
steps.content: Use an acrylic latex paint. Decide whether you want your finish to be glossy or matte, and look for an acrylic latex paint with that finish. You can find acrylic latex paint at your local hardware or paint store. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Apply the first coat of paint using a brush or roller.
steps.content: Apply the first coat of paint using a brush or roller. Paint using short, even strokes going in the same direction. It’s OK if the first coat looks slightly patchy or uneven. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Let the paint dry for at least two hours.
steps.content: Let the paint dry for at least two hours. Some paints may take longer to dry, so check the label on the paint you’re using for specific drying instructions. After two hours check to see if the first coat of paint is dry using your fingertips. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Alternate between painting and drying until you get an even coverage.
steps.content: Alternate between painting and drying until you get an even coverage. This could take between three to four coats of paint. Allow the furniture to dry for at least two hours between each coat. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Let the newly-painted furniture cure for a week.
steps.content: Let the newly-painted furniture cure for a week. You can re-attach any handles or knobs to the furniture once the final coat is dry, but avoid setting anything on the furniture until it's cured for a week to prevent peeling. You can also add a paint sealer to the surface of the furniture after the last coat dries. [13] X Research source
